source_title: Chris Williamson newsletter — The Dark Side Of Monk Mode (plus sleep, quotes & life hacks)

slides.text:
**Monk Mode can make you better — and quietly ruin your life.**
Why the retreat that improves you can also stop you from ever showing up.

**What is Monk Mode?**
A temporary retreat to focus on the 3 I’s: **Introspection, Isolation, Improvement.**
People use it to eliminate distractions and work on themselves full-time.

**It’s not new.**
Illimitable Man described it in 2014 as a deliberate cut-off from the world to recalibrate focus — and warned it can become a serious commitment.

A personal datapoint:
I’ve done full Monk Mode across 2017–2021.
**2000+ days** no alcohol, **500 days** no caffeine, **1500+** meditation sessions — mostly alone in a bedroom in Newcastle upon Tyne.

The problem: Monk Mode feels noble.
It **justifies retreat** from risk, adventure and friendship under the banner of self-improvement.
That justification is how it becomes sticky — and then permanent.

Example: a friend prepped for a fitness show — introverted, socially shy — used the competition to justify militant isolation.
The show passed. The routine didn’t. It took years to rebuild his social life.

Key idea: **Private practice is for public performance.**
Do your work in solitude so you can better **show up** in the world — not to replace showing up altogether.
Bill Perkins: “delayed gratification in the extreme results in no gratification.”

**How to avoid the trap:** Periodise your Monk Mode.
Set an end date. **3–6 months** is a sweet spot (longer if you’ve never done it before).
Use solitude to train — then return and perform.
**If you sleep 6 hours, you’re performing like someone awake 24 hours — but you probably won’t feel it.**

A landmark sleep test put people on **4h, 6h, or 8h** per night for **14 days**.
Cognitive performance was measured every two hours.

By day 14 the results were stark:
**6 hours/night = same impairment as 24 hours awake.**
**4 hours/night = same as 48 hours awake.**

From day 3–4 people stopped feeling subjectively more tired — but their reaction times, attention and working memory continued to decline.
Your brain hides the decline.

Most adults need **7–9 hours**.
Saying “I only need 6” usually means **you forgot what normal feels like.**
Feeling fine ≠ functioning well. (h/t Aakash Gupta)

**Action:** Recalibrate for two weeks: aim for 7–9h and compare performance.
If you’re on 6h and think you’re OK — assume you’ve lost calibration until proven otherwise.
Save this post for when you cut corners on sleep.

**“Life shrinks or expands according to one’s courage.” — Anaïs Nin**
Founders: the scale of what you get is set by the size of the risks you’ll take.

**Your life does not need to be easier — it needs to be simpler.**
You can handle hard. You can’t handle messy. Remove complexity before you ask for mercy.

**Jet lag only happens if you permit yourself to be time-cucked.**
Try refusing to change timezones on short trips: stay on your home schedule.
Example: Chris stayed on “CWT” (home time) while in Qatar — worked for 3 days.
